title: Electric PE - point charges Q1 Q2 and -Q3

content.question: System <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></math> consists of two positive point charges <math alttext="positive Q sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>+</mo><msub><mi>Q</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mpadded></math> and <math alttext="positive Q sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>+</mo><msub><mi>Q</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mpadded></math> fixed in place a small distance <math alttext="d" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>d</mi></math> apart, as shown in the figure. System <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi></math> consists of the same two point charges and a third, negative, point charge <math alttext="negative Q sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>-</mo><msub><mi>Q</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></mpadded></math> fixed in place near the original two positive point charges. The electric potential energies of System <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></math> and System <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi></math> are <math alttext="U sub X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>U</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></msub></math> and <math alttext="U sub Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>U</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi></msub></math>, respectively. How do <math alttext="U sub X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>U</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></msub></math> and <math alttext="U sub Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>U</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi></msub></math> compare to one another, and what evidence or reasoning supports the comparison?

choices.label: <math alttext="U sub X is greater than U sub Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>U</mi><mtext>X</mtext></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>U</mi><mtext>Y</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>. An external force must do negative work to move point charge <math alttext="negative Q sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>-</mo><msub><mi>Q</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></mpadded></math> from far away to its final position.

<math alttext="U sub X is greater than U sub Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>U</mi><mtext>X</mtext></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>U</mi><mtext>Y</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>. The electric field due to the positive point charges must do negative work on point charge <math alttext="negative Q sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>-</mo><msub><mi>Q</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></mpadded></math> as <math alttext="negative Q sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>-</mo><msub><mi>Q</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></mpadded></math> moves from far away to its final position.

<math alttext="U sub Y is greater than U sub X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>U</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>U</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></msub></mstyle></math>. The electric field due to the positive point charges must do positive work on point charge <math alttext="negative Q sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>-</mo><msub><mi>Q</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></mpadded></math> as <math alttext="negative Q sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>-</mo><msub><mi>Q</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></mpadded></math> moves from far away to its final position.

<math alttext="U sub Y is greater than U sub X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>U</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>U</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></msub></mstyle></math>. The force between point charge <math alttext="negative Q sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>-</mo><msub><mi>Q</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></mpadded></math> and each positive point charge is attractive.

content.answer: <math alttext="U sub X is greater than U sub Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>U</mi><mtext>X</mtext></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>U</mi><mtext>Y</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>. An external force must do negative work to move point charge <math alttext="negative Q sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>-</mo><msub><mi>Q</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></mpadded></math> from far away to its final position.

skill.text: 2.A: Derive a symbolic expression from known quantities by selecting and following a logical mathematical pathway.
